awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ECR DBER DCL: Extending a Theoretical Model for Undergraduate Students' Reflection and Abstraction of Proof Structures in Transition to Proofs Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will build upon promising teaching experiments that have already been conducted to develop theory about how students develop understandings of logical structure when learning mathematical proof. The project will begin with an initial model of students' Reflection and Abstraction of Proof Structures based on findings from existing studies and will develop and extend this model through a series of new teaching experiments. In the third year of the project, the model will be used to analyze students in classrooms. At the heart of this approach is helping students apprehend the questions of logic as they abstract their own mathematical activity to address those questions. The project will organically develop insights into students' content-general learning of logical relations as it emerges from within their content-specific reasoning about the specific mathematical relations.

Though engaging in mathematical proof is a central part of an undergraduate mathematics course of study, and the body of research on student learning in this arena is burgeoning, there do not exist research-based learning goals for the Transition to Proof courses being offered by many mathematics departments. Using grounded theory, this project will conduct teaching experiments with Calculus 3 students and analyze recordings of these sessions to refine and extend a constructivist theory of how learning occurs. The concept of abstraction and other constructs from Piaget will be prominent. This project is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances fundamental research on STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to learn how students can construct understanding of mathematical logic by reflecting on mathematical statements and arguments. By reflecting on how different mathematical statements have the same form, such as:

"Given any quadrilateral, if it is a square then it is a rectangle." and

"Given any integer x, if x is a multiple of 6, then x is a multiple of 3."

students can come to identify general rules for when "if... then..." statements in mathematics are true or false. This is a crucial development for doing proof-based mathematics, which is often a challenge for many mathematics majors and minors. Proof-based mathematics involves making mathematical language precise and using language in more rule-based ways than we do in other settings. Teaching by comparing mathematical statements helps students understand the goals of logic (to make language unambiguous and uniform) as they learn various logical relationships (e.g., negation, contrapositive equivalence, and converse independence). This way of helping students understand what problems logic intends to solve, or what questions it answers, seems especially important for supporting a linguistically diverse population to learn mathematical language with meaning and insight. Our project was conducted at two Hispanic-Serving Institutions, which made our focus on student language practices all the more important.

By studying student learning in laboratory environments, we investigated how student language needed to shift to be more conducive to proof-based mathematics, how students needed to think differently about mathematical terms to support mathematical logic, and how they could use these ways of reasoning to understand rules of mathematical proving. Our research reports documented these key insights about student reasoning and learning.

As a byproduct of studying student learning, we developed a sequence of instructional tasks that can be used in early proof classes to help students learn about sets, logic, and proof techniques. These instructional materials are being incorporated into broader instructional materials for undergraduate introduciton to proof courses in another grant project (NSF DUE#2141925), and will be made freely available online.

One key contribution we see from this project is making the logic curriculum more responsive to student language practices. Our use of teaching experiments allowed us to study student langauge use at a very fine-grained level and to move at the pace of student insight. This allowed us to negotiate very carefully what did and did not make sense to students. Through a long sequence of such experiments (and some corroborating studies from psychology, philosophy, and mathematics education), we have become convinced that grounding logic in sets of objects is more consistent with many students' untrained language practices than the standard approach to logic rooted in truth-tables. In situations like this where different mathematical formulations are equally valid, if one is more amenable to student reasoning we see that as a reason for the curriculum to respond to student insight. We hope the outcomes of this project will help support making the curriculum more accountable to student thinking in this local domain of teaching and learning.
